mighty standard component

Source: vignettes/mighty-standards.Rmd
mighty-standards.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette provides a step-by-step guide for creating standard components for they {mighty} framework. By following these conventions and using our custom roxygen2 tags, you will create components that are consistent, well-documented, and easily integrated into the existing ecosystem.

What is a Standard Component?

In the {mighty} framework, a “component” is a function that processes input data and returns a modified version with new columns or rows. Standard components share a common structure and documentation pattern, facilitating their use inside {mighty}.

Custom Roxygen Tags

Our package extends the standard {roxygen2} with special “Mighty” tags that help document specialized functions. These tags enable:

  1. Clear identification of function types
  2. Explicit declaration of data dependencies
  3. Documentation of output variables

The available tags are always required and are:

Tag Description Example
@type Specifies type: predecessor, derivation, row @type derivation
@depends Lists required input variables @depends .self USUBJID
@outputs Declares variables created @outputs NEWVAR

Component Conventions

Standard components follow these conventions:

  1. The first parameter is always named .self (the input dataset)
  2. Additional parameters represent other datasets or configuration options
  3. The function returns the modified .self dataset with new variables
  4. The function is documented using standard {roxygen2} tags and the custom tags mentioned above
  5. Documentation includes specific information about type, dependencies, and outputs
  6. Include an example using appropriate data from {pharmaversesdtm} and {pharmaverseadam}
  7. Any new component will have a corresponding unit test

Creating a New Component

Every component should follow this basic structure:

#' Component title
#' @description
#' A short description of what the component does...
#'
#' @param .self `data.frame` Input dataset
#' @param param1 Other parameters as needed
#' @param param2 Other parameters as needed
#'
#' @type [component type]
#' @depends [input dependencies: {data} {variable}]
#' @outputs [output variables: One entry per new variable]
#'
#' @returns `.self` with added/modified variables
#' @export
your_new_component <- function(.self, param1, param2) {
  # Implementation that transforms .self
  # ...
  return(.self)
}

Example

Let’s examine a more real example:

#' Dummy component creating a Albumin grouping variable
#' @description
#' Based on the baseline readings (`ABLFL == "Y"`) for Albumin
#' (`PARAMCD == "ALB"`) a new grouping variable (`ALBBLGRP`) is
#' added with the following intervals:
#'
#' * Albumin levels at least 40 g/L: ">= 40 g/L"
#' * Albumin levels below 40 g/L: "< 40 g/L"
#' * Missing or no baseline levels: "Missing"
#'
#' @param .self `data.frame` Input
#' @param adlb `data.frame` ADLB data set
#' @type derivation
#' @depends .self USUBJID
#' @depends adlb USUBJID
#' @depends adlb PARAMCD
#' @depends adlb AVAL
#' @outputs ALBBLGRP
#' @returns `.self` with added subject level Albumin grouping at baseline
#' @examples
#' pharmaverseadam::adsl |>
#'   dplyr::select(USUBJID) |>
#'   dummy(adlb = pharmaverseadam::adlb)
#'
#' @export
dummy <- function(.self, adlb) {
  x <- adlb |>
    dplyr::filter(.data$PARAMCD == "ALB", .data$ABLFL == "Y") |>
    dplyr::transmute(
      .data$USUBJID,
      ALBBLGRP = dplyr::case_when(
        .data$AVAL >= 40 ~ ">= 40 g/L",
        !is.na(.data$AVAL) ~ "< 40 g/L",
        TRUE ~ "Missing"
      )
    )

  .self <- .self |>
    dplyr::left_join(x, by = "USUBJID") |>
    dplyr::mutate(ALBBLGRP = dplyr::coalesce(.data$ALBBLGRP, "Missing"))

  return(.self)
}

This generates the following roxygen documentation with a custom “Mighty” that appears below the standard roxygen sections:

% Generated by roxygen2: do not edit by hand
% Please edit documentation in mighty.standards/dummy.R
\name{dummy}
\alias{dummy}
\title{Dummy component creating a Albumin grouping variable}
\usage{
dummy(.self, adlb)
}
\arguments{
\item{.self}{`data.frame` Input}

\item{adlb}{`data.frame` ADLB data set}
}
\value{
`.self` with added subject level Albumin grouping at baseline
}
\description{
Based on the baseline readings (`ABLFL == "Y"`) for Albumin
(`PARAMCD == "ALB"`) a new grouping variable (`ALBBLGRP`) is
added with the following intervals:

* Albumin levels at least 40 g/L: ">= 40 g/L"
* Albumin levels below 40 g/L: "< 40 g/L"
* Missing or no baseline levels: "Missing"
}
\examples{
pharmaverseadam::adsl |>
  dplyr::select(USUBJID) |>
  dummy(adlb = pharmaverseadam::adlb)

}
\section{Mighty}{
\subsection{Type}{
derivation
}
\subsection{Depends}{
\itemize{
\item .self.USUBJID
\item adlb.USUBJID
\item adlb.PARAMCD
\item adlb.AVAL
}
}
\subsection{Outputs}{
\itemize{
\item ALBBLGRP
}
}
}
